docs.lead_paragraph: The Asian connection to the campaign fund-raising controversy roiling the White House appears to have originated in a crucial series of meetings that President Clinton held for seven days in September 1995. A reconstruction of events from Government documents, published accounts and interviews with participants shows that the meetings centered on the decision to start an unusual, early and expensive series of television advertisements -- and ultimately on how to raise the tens of millions of dollars to pay for them.

headline.main: Clinton Ad Plan Led to Asian-American Donors

docs.abstract: Asian connection to the campaign fund-raising controversy at White House appears to have originated in a crucial series of meetings that Pres Clinton held in September 1995 at which he accepted John Huang's offer to leave his post at Commerce Department to raise money for Democratic National Committee, which was broke and in need of money to pay for an unusual, early and expensive series of television advertisements; ads were intended to define the Clinton's Presidency, but Harold Ickes sugge sted that they could be made to address issues, rather than Clinton the candidate, so that they might be paid for with the committee's 'soft money' rather than the campaign's 'hard money,' which was limited by law and which Ickes wanted held in reserve in case there was a Democratic challenger; Huang worked out the idea of targeting 'overseas Chinese' donors in subsequent meeting with Ickes; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The brand-new wrought-iron staircase, lighted by ornamental lampposts, connects the gothic splendor of Trinity College to the blight of the Frog Hollow neighborhood below. The stairs are a small thing, compared with the $175 million that will be spent on schools, job training, mortgage assistance and family services in the 15 blocks that surround -- and imprison -- the 173-year-old college.

headline.main: Trinity College Leads Effort To Spark Hartford's Renewal

docs.abstract: Trinity College president Evan S Dobelle has used Trinity College's financial resources and prestige to galvanize other large neighborhood institutions, government and private industry to save blighted neighborhood around Hartford, Conn, school for its largely Puerto Rican residents; area institutions have put up $10 million in seed money for $175 million plan to provide safe streets, stable home ownership, state-of-the-art schools and jobs; program is model for other urban colleges that are reaching out into crumbling communities; photos (L)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: While the rookie doctors at Maimonides Medical Center expected their lives as interns and residents to be hectic routines of long hours, sleepless nights and tough hands-on training, they say that lately they are being forced to go beyond the call of duty. To help improve working conditions there, some doctors banded together to form a union. But in that effort, they say, they have been confronted by a backlash from the top administrators at the hospital. Maimonides officials have refused to recognize C.I.R, the Committee of Interns and Residents, the union some doctors would like to see form a chapter at the hospital.

headline.main: Student Doctors Lock Horns With Hospital Over Union

docs.abstract: Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, rebuffs efforts by interns and residents to unionize; refuses to recognize Committee of Interns and Residents; student doctors complain of worsening working conditions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. Vincent T. Beni sat in his office at the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services here, lamenting the format that turned a tiger into an elephant. His proposed budget was sleeker than it had been in years, but certain compulsory figures gave the opposite impression. ''We don't like the word budget,'' Dr. Beni, the board's Superintendent, said. ''We would prefer to use the term tuition rate.''

headline.main: School Units to Vote On Budget for Board

docs.abstract: Thirty-two school districts that are members of Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services to vote on board's $4.3 million administrative budget; Supt Vincent T Beni says overall budget is up 6.2 percent from current year, despite 1.2 percent cut in day-to-day expenses, because of 23% jump in retirement benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CLAIMING they lacked protection from the very community they risk their lives to guard, police officers here engaged in a high-profile battle to gain public sympathy in their efforts to obtain better medical benefits during contract negotiations with the village. The Scarsdale Police Benevolent Association and the Village reached a tentative agreement recently, which included extended health insurance after retirement, among other contract provisions. But the agreement came after the union took out advertisements in the local newspaper, testified in front of the Village Board and threatened a public picket in the quaint downtown of this wealthy enclave.

headline.main: Scarsdale Police Reach a New Pact

docs.abstract: Scarsdale, NY, and its police officers recently reached tentative contract accord, which includes extended health insurance after retirement; pact follows high-profile drive by Scarsdale Police Benevolent Association for improved benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TWENTY-THREE years after the New England Whalers of the old World Hockey Association relocated, name and all, to Hartford -- a city renown for insurance but not for seafaring -- the team is leaving. Now known as the Hartford Whalers, it plays its last regular season game tonight at the Hartford Civic Center. By next fall, the Whalers are expected to be in Columbus, Ohio (the first choice of the Whalers' owner, Peter Karamanos), St. Paul, Minn., or the Raleigh-Durham area in North Carolina. ''We're done in Hartford, and there's no way we're coming back,'' Mr. Karamanos said in an interview from his home in a Detroit suburb. ''We gave it the old college try, but the economics just didn't work. And we lost an awful lot of money.'' Mr. Karamanos -- bitterly assailed for deciding to move the Whalers out of Hartford by Hartford sports writers, some legislators, Hartford Mayor Mike Peters (who threatened to hit Mr. Karamanos in the head if he saw him on a Hartford street) and in vituperative letters to the editor of The Hartford Courant by Whaler fans -- will not be on hand to watch his team play Tampa Bay tonight. ''I don't think it would be a good idea for me to be there,'' he said.

headline.main: Splitsville For Hartford And the Whalers

docs.abstract: Many Hartford, Conn, residents and officials are embittered by decision by Hartford Whalers owner Peter Karamanos to move team elsewhere; team's departure will leave void at Hartford Civic Center, where it has been main tenant, and will rob Connecticut of its only major league team; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate leaders are urging Republicans not to back a children's health insurance bill sponsored by Senators Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, and one of the bill's original eight Republican supporters dropped off today. After Senator Robert F. Bennett, another Utah Republican, announced today that he was withdrawing the support he had promised on Tuesday, Mr. Hatch said: ''I am disappointed, but I accept whatever my colleague wants to do. As for me, I am going to fight my guts out for these kids.''

headline.main: G.O.P. Fights Bill to Offer A Health Plan For Children

docs.abstract: Senate leaders urge fellow Republicans not to support Hatch-Kennedy bill to provide health insurance for children whose families do not have coverage; Sen Robert Bennett withdraws support; Sen Orrin Hatch vows to press fight to raise cigarette taxes to finance plan (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Webster L. Hubbell announced his resignation as Associate Attorney General in March 1994 and -- with the knowledge of Hillary Rodham Clinton -- began to seek financial support from friends of the White House, the Administration knew that Mr. Hubbell had already emerged as a crucial witness in several politically sensitive investigations of President Clinton and the First Lady. Shortly before his resignation, Mr. Hubbell was interrogated by Federal regulators from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation about the role he and Mrs. Clinton had played in the 1980's, when they represented a savings association that ended up accused of corruption. At the time, several subpoenas had already been issued by the newly appointed Whitewater independent counsel about a fraudulent land transaction in which Mr. Hubbell's father-in-law had played an important role and which, it was later discovered, Mrs. Clinton also provided some legal work.

headline.main: White House Knew in '94 That Hubbell Was Focus of Inquiry

docs.abstract: Federal and Congressional investigators reconstruct events at White House in 1994 as Pres and Mrs Clinton came under pressure with regard to ties to Madison Savings and Loan in Arkansas; Administration knew in March that Webster Hubbell was crucial witness; March was when Hillary Clinton's former law partner resigned from Justice Department and, with her knowledge, sought financial help from Clinton friends; he was questioned just before resignation by FDIC about his and Mrs Clinton's role in representing Madison Savings in 1980's Clintons have said they were unaware of depth of Hubbell's legal problems when he resigned (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-6 U.S. and Europe Agree To Agree on Cuba The European Union and the United States agreed on a plan to resolve their dispute over sanctions against Cuba. A European complaint that was to have gone before the World Trade Organization on Monday will be suspended pending negotiations. The Clinton Administration agreed to seek a change in the Helms-Burton sanctions law; its prospects in Congress were unclear. 1 Iran Shunned, but Not by Russia Russia warmly welcomed the head of Iran's parliament and vowed to improve ties with Iran. His visit came a day after a German court said the Iranian Government had ordered the assassination of exiled dissidents, a ruling that prompted most European Union countries to recall their ambassadors from Teheran. Russia's courting of Iran was seen as an effort to placate anti-Western Russian nationalists. 5
